column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: With the assistance of the Nomination Committee, the Board reviews Board succession on an ongoing basis and, in doing so, considers the mix of skills and experience on the Board, the performance of its Directors and the diversity represented on the Board. In addition, the Nomination Committee regularly considers succession planning to ensure an orderly succession and renewal of the Directors.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: The Chairman, Robert Millner AO, joined the Board in December 1995 and was appointed Chairman in November 1998.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board has a charter that outlines its responsibilities, including powers expressly reserved to the Board and powers specifically delegated to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and Management. In particular, the Board is responsible for overseeing the management of New Hope Group; setting strategic objectives; monitoring the Company's financial, operational and sustainability performance; approving the Group's Code of Conduct and Governance Policies; setting the risk appetite and monitoring the Group's risk management; and compliance with the Company's governance frameworks and regulatory compliance.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Board delegates certain powers to Board Committees to help fulfil its roles and responsibilities. The Board has delegated the CEO power and authority to manage the Company's business, except for those matters expressly reserved to the Board or one of its Committees.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Board recognises that risk management and internal controls are fundamental to sound management, and oversight of such matters is a crucial responsibility of the Board. The Sustainability Committee (SC) (formerly the Sustainability and People Committee) assists the Board in meeting its obligations concerning health, safety, well-being, environment, community and people matters. The SC is primarily responsible for managing risks allocated to it and reporting and updating the Board about climate change and sustainability matters.
column13: At least annually, in conjunction with the Audit and Risk Committee (ARC) and consultation with responsible executives and employees, the SC reviews the Group's risk register and risk management framework and agrees on allocating responsibility by respective committees per identified risk.

We acknowledge climate change is a critical global issue that requires an international effort to transition to a net zero carbon economy while maintaining reliable and secure energy sources as the role and extent of coal, oil, and gas change over time. Our role is to safely, responsibly and efficiently operate our low-unit cost, long-life assets while the demand for coal used to generate energy continues. Importantly, companies that responsibly manage operational impacts on the environment, people and communities are the most appropriate operators to produce the coal required through the energy transition.

column8: Freedom of Association and Collective Bargaining
column13: All employees have the right to form or join a trade union, bargain collectively, and engage in trade union activities. Under Australia's industrial relations framework, enterprise agreements (EAs) are negotiated collectively with employees and their bargaining and union representatives. New EAs are usually negotiated every three or four years, and final contracts are approved by and registered with the Fair Work Commission and made publicly available.
